bestBHT.bht: Paul had originally intended to visit the Corinthians, but he now tacitly drops this scheme and announces another out of tenderness towards them. His change of plan had been captiously charged with 'lightness,' but his real motive was lenity towards them. Paul expresses his matured plan to pass through Macedonia and visit them on his return journey. This change of plan had been falsely criticized, when in reality it was motivated by concern for their welfare. He acknowledges the need to submit to God's providence in all future plans.

Henry Alford: This plan was a change from his former intention...he now tacitly drops this scheme, and announces another.
For this he was charged with levity of purpose...but his real motive was, lenity towards them.
The present tense implies his now matured plan.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This is what I at last resolve upon.
He was not yet in Macedonia, but at Ephesus; but he was thinking of passing through it.
Albert Barnes: Now I will come unto you - I purpose to come unto you.
When I shall pass through Macedonia - When I shall have passed through Macedonia.
For I do pass through Macedonia - I design to do it. It is my present intention.
John Calvin: For what reason had he for delay, except that he was concerned as to their welfare?

On the other hand, he lets them know how fully assured he is of their affection towards him in return, by taking it, as it were, for granted that he would be conducted forward by them in the way of kindness.

The main thing indeed is, that, in the inward affection of the mind, we submit to God and his providence, whatever we resolve upon; but at the same time, it is becoming that we should accustom ourselves to such forms of expression, that whenever we have to do with what is future we may make everything depend on the divine will.
Philip Schaff: But I will come unto you, when I shall have passed through Macedonia; for I do pass through Macedonia ‘I am going to do so.’
He now announces only one visit, and that on his return journey.
For this change of plan he had been captiously charged with 'lightness' (fickleness, insincerity, 2 Corinthians 1:17); whereas it was out of tenderness to them...
Archibald T. Robertson: Whenever I pass through (second aorist active subjunctive of διερχομα) Macedonia
I do pass through (διερχομα). I plan to pass through
John Gill: Now I will come unto you...though some had given out that he would not come to them any more."
hereby fixing the time when he intended to visit them after he had gone through that country.
but the sense is, that he should take his tour through Macedonia; and so the Vulgate Latin version renders it, 'for I shall pass through Macedonia'.
John Wesley: I pass through Macedonia — I purpose going that way.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul had originally intended to visit the Corinthians, but he now reveals his change in plans. This change was not due to fickleness or insincerity, but out of tenderness towards them. He announces his matured plan to pass through Macedonia and then visit them on his return journey. This change of plan had been falsely criticized as a sign of lightness, when in reality it was motivated by concern for their welfare. Paul expresses his assurance of their affection towards him, assuming that they will kindly support him during his travels. Ultimately, he acknowledges that all future plans are dependent on the divine will, emphasizing the submission to God's providence.

Paul originally intended to visit the Corinthians, but his plan changed out of tenderness towards them. He now resolves to pass through Macedonia and visit them on his return journey. Although his change of plan was falsely criticized as being fickle, it was actually motivated by concern for their welfare. Paul expresses his assurance of their affection for him and the expectation that they will support him. He acknowledges that all future plans are subject to the divine will, emphasizing the need to submit to God's providence.

Although his change of plan was falsely criticized as being fickle, it was actually motivated by concern for their welfare. Paul expresses his assurance of their affection and the expectation of their support. He acknowledges that future plans are subject to the divine will, emphasizing the need to submit to God's providence.

Paul had originally intended to visit the Corinthians, but he now tacitly drops this scheme and announces another out of tenderness towards them. His change of plan had been captiously charged with 'lightness,' but his real motive was lenity towards them. Paul expresses his matured plan to pass through Macedonia and visit them on his return journey. This change of plan had been falsely criticized, when in reality it was motivated by concern for their welfare. He acknowledges the need to submit to God's providence in all future plans.

Paul initially planned to visit the Corinthians, but he now announces a change out of tenderness towards them. He resolves to pass through Macedonia and visit them on his return journey. This change is wrongly accused of fickleness, yet it is driven by concern for their welfare. Paul assures of their affection and their expected support. He recognizes that future plans are subject to the divine will, highlighting the importance of submitting to God's providence.
